comments.body: can we move this into util.config? really want to cut down the number of top level packages.

comments.body: I could move the builder classes into util, but it doesn't really make a lot of sense to move the actual configs to the util package, since they'd feel out of place there. They're the config entries for Spark, not for the Spark util package.

comments.body:
Sure - maybe move that into internal.config.

We have been creating top-level packages in ad-hoc ways and those are really polluting the docs. I'm trying to cut down those. The big chasm is that as developers, we only think about the structure of the project as a developer of the project. However, what we should really be thinking about is from the end-user's perspective.

comments.body:
I'm a little confused. Wouldn't `internal.config` also show up in the docs? What makes something do or do not show up in docs? What's the new convention for adding new private Spark types to the code base?

Everything here is `private[spark]`, except for the package objects which Scala doesn't allow being `private` anything. So what would show up in the docs here and potentially confuse people?

comments.body:
if we introdue internal, we can move a lot of the internal stuff into it. this is similar to what netty does.

private[spark] has no impact on java.  as part of spark 2.0, one of the api item I had on the dev list email was to clean up the mess that our current package makes no sense from an end-user point of view.

comments.body:
> private[spark] has no impact on java

At what level? Yes, the method in the java class file is public, but it doesn't seem to actually show up in any documentation. e.g. in http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/api/java/index.html you don't see things like `SparkConf.validateSettings`, which is `private[spark]`.

I don't like putting things in specially-named packages in hope that people will not look at them, but if it means I can get this change moving, I'll move classes into whatever package.
